Description: Gold ear-ring in the form of a plain wire hook with a small knob at one end and an oval convex shield at the other.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Found by locals looting the site between 1884-5 “south-west of the town at a high part, lying in the loose dust among the houses”
Curator's comments: Acquired by Petrie in Naukratis 'A man brought me a small gold earring & handed it to me to weigh, quite contented that I booked it as his; the gold was worth 2/- with which he was well content' (Petrie Journal 1884-5, 166).

This earring is of common 1st century AD type (Marshall 1911, 304, no. 2635), and it was probably found with a group of gold and silver votive offerings dating to the period c. AD 67–98 (discussed below), but acquired separately from that group, from locals looting the site (Petrie Journal 1884–5, 166), suggesting that other Roman gold jewellery objects acquired in both 1884–5 and 1885–6 seasons may have come from the same original structure. Marshall, F.H. 1911, Catalogue of the Jewellery, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman, in the Departments of Antiquities, British Museum, London.
Bibliographic references: Jewellery / Catalogue of the Jewellery, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman, in the Departments of Antiquities, British Museum. (2635)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 43-4, pl. XXVII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (QE.1)
